details.title: Dominant multi-state systems

p: Jinsheng Huang received his B.S. (1982) and M.S. (1988) in Mechanical Engineering from the University of Science and Technology Beijing. He is pursing his Ph.D. in Mechanical Engineering at the University of Alberta. His research interests include reliability and mechanical design.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Mech. Eng., Univ. of Alberta, Edmonton, Alta., Canada
authors.name: Jinsheng Huang

p: Ming J. Zuo received a Bachelor of Science in Agricultural Engineering from Shandong Institute of Technology in 1982, following with his Master of Science in 1986 and Ph.D. in 1989 both in Industrial Engineering from Iowa State University, Ames, Iowa, U.S.A. He worked at the University of Windsor in Canada for a year in 1989. He is currently Professor in the Department of Mechanical Engineering at the University of Alberta. His research interests include system reliability, manufacturing systems, and applied operations research. He is Associate Editor for IEEE Transactions on Reliability, and a member of the editorial board of the journal IIE Transactions on Quality and Reliability Engineering. He is a senior member of IEEE and IIE.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Mech. Eng., Univ. of Alberta, Edmonton, Alta., Canada
authors.name: M.J. Zuo

details.abstract: In this paper, we propose a definition of the dominant multi-state system. Under the proposed definition, multi-state systems are divided into two groups without reference to component relevancy conditions: dominant systems, and nondominant systems. Dominant systems can be further divided into two groups: with binary image, and without binary image. A multi-state system with binary image implies that its structure function can be expressed in terms of binary structure functions such that it can be treated as a binary system structure, and existing algorithms for reliability evaluation of binary systems can be applied for system performance evaluation. A technique is provided for establishing the bounds of performance distribution of dominant systems without binary image. The properties of dominant systems are studied. Examples are given to illustrate applications of the proposed definitions and methods.

context.text: Among binary systems with \$n\$ components, the series structure is the weakest structure, while the parallel structure is the strongest structure because \$\prod _{i=1}^{n}x_{i}\leq \phi ({\bf x})\leq 1-\prod _{i=1}^{n}(1-x_{i})\$ [3].

context.text: Many authors have concentrated on extending the relevancy conditions from the binary case to the multi-state case; for example, see Barlow & Wu [4], Griffith [6], and Xue [10].

context.text: Block and Savits [5] propose a decomposition theorem for multi-state structure functions, where the states of all components are represented by \$n \times M\$ binary variables, i.e., \$(x_{11},\ldots, x_{1M},x_{21},\ldots, x_{2M}, \ldots, x_{n1}, \ldots, x_{nM})\$.

references.title: A decomposition for multi-state monotone systems
references.text: H. W. Block, T. H. Savits, "A decomposition for multi-state monotone systems", J. Appl. Prob., vol. 19, pp. 391-401, 1982.

links.abstract: This paper shows how to model a multistate system with multistate components using binary variables. This modeling technique allows current binary algorithms for block diagrams and fault trees to be applied to multistate systems. Several multistate examples are presented, and some cases in which computational efficiency can be enhanced are discussed.

context.text: Wood [9] proposes that multi-state system be analyzed using existing binary algorithms by means of the multi-state block diagrams.

references.title: Multi-state block diagrams and fault trees
references.text: P. A. Wood, "Multi-state block diagrams and fault trees", IEEE Trans. Rel., vol. R-34, pp. 236-240, 1985.

links.abstract: Discrete function theory, which extends switching function theory and multiple-valued logic function theory, is introduced into multistate system analysis. Some theoretical conclusions and algorithms which play key roles in multistate system analysis are presented. The concepts of s-coherence and duality in binary-state system analysis are generalized. The set of minimal upper (maximum lower) vectors for level j, which play the role of min path (cut) set, is introduced to represent the states of...

context.text: Many authors have concentrated on extending the relevancy conditions from the binary case to the multi-state case; for example, see Barlow & Wu [4], Griffith [6], and Xue [10].
Sometimes the enumeration method may be easier to use for simple systems [10].

references.title: On multi-state system analysis
